column1: The Red Arrow was a way Gondor summoned its allies in time of need.
Its flights were black and its barbs were made of steel
column2: and it took its name from a mark of red painted on the arrows tip
column3: standing for blood to show the situation was serious. The black flights were like the Orcs arrows.

column1: First mention of the Red Arrow is when Borondir of Gondor and five other messengers rode north along Anduin to seek out Gondors old allies
column3: when Gondor was being overrun by Easterlings
column4: in . Borondir was the only survivor
column5: and presented the Red Arrow to the Éothéod King Eorl the Young.

column1: It is not certain where the Red Arrow came from: it is possible that the tradition was an old one and that Gondor had always summoned its allies this way
column2: but another possibility is that Borondir actually took an Orc arrow with a bloody tip to present to the Éothéod
column3: to prove that the situation was as bad as his message stated.

column1: On 9 March  it became a summons for the Rohirrim. The Red Arrow was presented to Rohan by Hirgon in the War of the Ring
column2: and Théoden King rode out with the Muster of Rohan to the Battle of the Pelennor Fields.
